Active transmission, as Justinian remarks, is the rule. Those rights os action only are excepted (ot which the actio iniuriarum is here taken as a type) which arc grounded not on a damnum or injury to property, but on a grievance or insult to the person; eg. among others, the querella inofficiosi testamenti, Dig. 5. 2. 6. 2, and the remedy os a patron or pater against a freedman or child who commenced legal proceedings against him without the praetors pennission, Tit.16.3ins. The chief exceptions to passive transmission are the actiones populares, Dig. 47. 23. 7. 8, and (as is observed in the text) penal actions arising ex delicto. Actione which are purely poenae persecutoriae are passively transmissible only when they are absolutely the only remedy on the wrong (e. g. the actio on calumnia, Dig. 3. 6. 5. pn), and then only sofar as the inheritauce has been enriched thereby; and this same principle ol the liability os the heir to the extent to which the inheritance has been benefited applies also to actions (ς) which, though grounded on delict, are purely rei persecutoriae (e. g. actio doli, Dig. ι, 3 17. 1, quod metus causa, Dig. 4 α. ι6. 2); (a) which are mixtae, except where an action which is purely rei persecutoria lies on the same delict (eg. the condictio furtiva on rapina, Dig. 47. 8. 2. 27).
